repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Fixes: https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/25857

Add a new `'termsync'` option that, when set, enables [Synchronized Output][1] mode, if supported by the terminal. The implementation first issues a DECRQM escape sequence to query the terminal for synchronized output support. If the terminal supports it, then synchronized output is controlled by the `'termsync'` setting.

When `'termsync'` is enabled (and supported by the terminal) then all screen updates done by Nvim are buffered/batched together to be displayed by the terminal emulator at once. This eliminates flickering/tearing in cases when the terminal emulator updates the screen faster than Nvim can draw it.

Other references:

- https://gitlab.com/gnachman/iterm2/-/wikis/synchronized-updates-spec

[1]: https://gist.github.com/christianparpart/d8a62cc1ab659194337d73e399004036

comment_data.body: `'sync'` as a short name is a bit non-specific. maybe we can have 'syncout` as the only name (it is just a vimism that options should have a too long name and a too short name, one single name is fully allowed)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -6256,6 +6256,14 @@ A jump table for the options with a short description can be found at |Q_op|.
 	   uselast	If included, jump to the previously used window when
 			jumping to errors with |quickfix| commands.
 
+			*'syncoutput'* *'sync'* *'nosyncoutput'* *'nosync'*
+'syncoutput' 'sync'	boolean	(default off)

@@ -6256,6 +6256,14 @@ A jump table for the options with a short description can be found at |Q_op|.
 	   uselast	If included, jump to the previously used window when
 			jumping to errors with |quickfix| commands.
 
+			*'syncoutput'* *'sync'* *'nosyncoutput'* *'nosync'*
+'syncoutput' 'sync'	boolean	(default off)

comment_data.body: I'd say "asks the terminal emulator to buffer", otherwise it sounds like it means a terminal emulator as part of nvim itself.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -211,6 +211,9 @@ The following new APIs and features were added.
 • A clipboard provider which uses OSC 52 to copy the selection to the system
   clipboard is now bundled by default. |clipboard-osc52|
 
+• The 'syncout' option buffers screen updates in the terminal emulator

comment_data.body: in docs I try to use the phrase "host terminal" to mean the terminal that contains the Nvim TUI
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -211,6 +211,9 @@ The following new APIs and features were added.
 • A clipboard provider which uses OSC 52 to copy the selection to the system
   clipboard is now bundled by default. |clipboard-osc52|
 
+• The 'syncout' option buffers screen updates in the terminal emulator

comment_data.body:
Why not default to "on"? (Does it even need to be optional?)

Shouldn't we prefix it with `term`, like `termguicolors`? That helps discoverability.

```suggestion
'termsyncout'		boolean	(default off)
```
If there's a chance this may be supported by all UIs in the future , the usual convention is to prefix it with `gui`
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -6254,6 +6254,14 @@ A jump table for the options with a short description can be found at |Q_op|.
 	   uselast	If included, jump to the previously used window when
 			jumping to errors with |quickfix| commands.
 
+						*'syncout'* *'nosyncout'*
+'syncout'		boolean	(default off)

comment_data.body: Actually, synchronized output makes sense for the terminal client as well as GUI clients. Why would the GUI not want to avoid tearing, if possible? How is this capability informed towards a potential GUI frontend?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -6254,6 +6254,14 @@ A jump table for the options with a short description can be found at |Q_op|.
 	   uselast	If included, jump to the previously used window when
 			jumping to errors with |quickfix| commands.
 
+						*'syncout'* *'nosyncout'*
+'syncout'		boolean	(default off)

comment_data.body:
> Why would the GUI not want to avoid tearing, if possible? 

Both Nvim UI protocol and Nvim UIs already try to batch screen updates.

So this option is likely irrelevant for GUIs. This PR merely sets a terminal feature which is not present in all terminals. Such a concept is irrelevant for GUIs.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -6254,6 +6254,14 @@ A jump table for the options with a short description can be found at |Q_op|.
 	   uselast	If included, jump to the previously used window when
 			jumping to errors with |quickfix| commands.
 
+						*'syncout'* *'nosyncout'*
+'syncout'		boolean	(default off)

comment_data.body:
> Why not default to "on"? (Does it even need to be optional?)
> 

My preference would also be for it to default to on and not be optional, but I was taking the conservative approach here. I’m fine with changing it if there’s no objection.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -6254,6 +6254,14 @@ A jump table for the options with a short description can be found at |Q_op|.
 	   uselast	If included, jump to the previously used window when
 			jumping to errors with |quickfix| commands.
 
+						*'syncout'* *'nosyncout'*
+'syncout'		boolean	(default off)

comment_data.body:
A developer might want to have the possibility to have it disabled, to interactively see the screen redrawn as the developer single-steps through each call in the code.

From the user's perspective, there is **zero** need to have this configurable, tbh - the developer (terminal as well as nvim or even nvim plugin dev) might very well want to control it.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -6254,6 +6254,14 @@ A jump table for the options with a short description can be found at |Q_op|.
 	   uselast	If included, jump to the previously used window when
 			jumping to errors with |quickfix| commands.
 
+						*'syncout'* *'nosyncout'*
+'syncout'		boolean	(default off)

comment_data.body: With TUI stuff historically we try to enable as much by default as possible. Easy to revert later if we run into unsolvable problems.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -6254,6 +6254,14 @@ A jump table for the options with a short description can be found at |Q_op|.
 	   uselast	If included, jump to the previously used window when
 			jumping to errors with |quickfix| commands.
 
+						*'syncout'* *'nosyncout'*
+'syncout'		boolean	(default off)

comment_data.body: +1 to make it the default. That would match existing GUI behaviors so guis could interpret explicitly setting it to false if it wants to (or just ignore it )
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -6254,6 +6254,14 @@ A jump table for the options with a short description can be found at |Q_op|.
 	   uselast	If included, jump to the previously used window when
 			jumping to errors with |quickfix| commands.
 
+						*'syncout'* *'nosyncout'*
+'syncout'		boolean	(default off)

comment_data.body: Sounds good 👍. If GUIs are meant to interpret this should we stick with 'syncout' over 'termsyncout' and make the help text more UI generic (rather than TUI specific)?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -6254,6 +6254,14 @@ A jump table for the options with a short description can be found at |Q_op|.
 	   uselast	If included, jump to the previously used window when
 			jumping to errors with |quickfix| commands.
 
+						*'syncout'* *'nosyncout'*
+'syncout'		boolean	(default off)

comment_data.body: I'd say `termsyncout` still. If a GUI ends up trying to care about this, that's a quirk similar to how some UIs look at `termguicolors`, but it's not a core recommendation.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -6254,6 +6254,14 @@ A jump table for the options with a short description can be found at |Q_op|.
 	   uselast	If included, jump to the previously used window when
 			jumping to errors with |quickfix| commands.
 
+						*'syncout'* *'nosyncout'*
+'syncout'		boolean	(default off)

comment_data.body: I see in earlier comments that 'sync' was the original name. So we could name this 'termsync', which is more readable and also leaves the door open for potentially non-output related "sync" behavior in the future.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -6523,6 +6523,14 @@ A jump table for the options with a short description can be found at |Q_op|.
 
 	   C1	    Control characters 0x80...0x9F
 
+					*'termsyncout'* *'notermsyncout'*
+'termsyncout'		boolean	(default on)

comment_data.body:
nit: the expansion of "synchronize" seems unusual
```suggestion
  tui_sync_output(tui, true);
```

Would these definitions be useful for `:terminal` in the future, e.g. when `:terminal` handles a child request (the inverse of what TUI is doing here)? Should these live in a header that is shared by both tui.c and terminal.c?

I guess libvterm should abstract that for us, so maybe not.
Happy to rename or move definitions around in the future if we ever need/want to, but I'll leave as-is for now.

comment_regular_data.body: Does this also need an update to `runtime/doc/ui.txt`

> Does this also need an update to `runtime/doc/ui.txt`

I don't think so, since that file covers external UIs and UI events and this is a TUI only feature. But if you had a specific suggestion in my mind I'm open to it.
I'm going to split out the commits in this PR so that this PR only adds the `'syncout'` option. I will move the `input.c` refactoring to a separate PR.
Option renamed to `termsyncout` and defaults to on. Other comments addressed as well. Will merge in the next ~day if there are no other comments.
Fixed a formatting failure and a test failure, will merge when CI is green.

title: TUI: support synchronized output
